Name: Butt Head
Description: Each player dons a hat covered with Velcro strips marked with different points.  There are three sponge balls also covered in Velcro strips so that they will stick to the hats.  Several different games can be played with the equipment, rules being provided for six variations.  The basic game involves the players throwing the balls at each other until they have all stuck - whichever player has scored the most points is the winner.

Name: Coalescence
Description:
From the website:

Coalescence is an abstract strategy game in which two to five players manipulate the movements of colossal crystalline nuggets of star-stuff in a spiral galaxy, attempting to create the largest stellar systems and capture them with their immense star-scoops! Can you choose between setting up a sweet chunk of fusion for yourself now, or grabbing a promising patch of space for yourself that might be worth a bundle later?

Each Coalescence set is lovingly handcrafted in Austin, TX. Contains 22" cloth board and 60 acrylic crystal nuggets, and 12 hand-painted wooden capture rings.

Name: Trivial Trivia: Idiot Edition
Description:
From the back of the box:
Tired of being called an idiot because the rest of the players seem to know something in every category and you appear to know nothing at all?  Then this is your chance to change all of that with Trivial Trivia "The Idiot Edition"  Trivial Trivia is so simple, you'll feel like Einstein.

With 6 different categories you can play it by itself or spike other trivia games and give yourself the winning edge.  Sit back, relax, and enjoy this new style of trivia.  It won't give you a headache, but you might get a side ache from laughing!

Contains 50 blue and white trivia cards in a double deck lidded box.

Name: Call of Duty Real-Time Card Game
Description:
CANCELLED GAME

    
    
         The information that BGG has on this item indicates that Call of Duty Real-Time Card Game will not enter production.  This entry currently serves as a placeholder for the announced item and will likely later be removed.

    


A real-time battle based card game where players deploy 3 soldiers to the battlefield from their squad deck. Action cards activate these soldiers, as they battle it out in real-time. Soldiers fire, move, dive for cover, and attack the enemy, with the first player to a  certain number of frags declared the winner. Decks from different countries can be combined to create new strategies.

Two players set up on a 5x5 grid and attempt to win through either earning a preset number of points won by kills or achieve some other mission based objective such as capture the flag. The different "game modes" are quite similar to what one would find in the video game upon which it is based.

The game plays in real time so players are forced to find a balance between speed and strategy. Each player has a deck from which they draw cards one at a time and play them as fast as they can (or discard them if they cannot be played). Certain cards trigger a pause in the action at which time all effects (except movement which is handled as it comes up) are resolved.

Each of the 8 different, but non-collectible, squad decks come with:

    60-card deck
    8 Soldier cards
    2 Mission cards
    Double-sided game map
    Rules sheet

Name: Wonder Garden
Description:
From the back of the box:
"This is a most interesting and instructive game. As many children can play as there are cards. Place all of the circular pieces in the center of the table and turn them all face down, then give each player a card. The object of the game is to complete the cards correctly. The first players selects one of the pieces. If it completes a figure in his card this player has another opportunity to draw and continues in this way until he draws a piece which does not belong in his card, which piece is put back on the table face down and mixed in with the others and the next in turn plays in the same way and so on until all have played. Continue playing in turn and the one whose card is complete first wins the game."

Note: Box claims a patent date of July 23, 1912

Name: Sentence Builders
Description:
Object of the game is to make high score by building a series of sentences with different word requirements. Cards are separated by various parts of speech (color coded. Each player gets a card rack and stores their cards like you would place your scrabble tiles. Instead of making words with letters you make sentences with words. 
The game is separated into 6 rounds/ There is different requirements for each round using verbs, nouns, adverbs, conjunction, interjection, adjective etc...
The winner is the player that earned the most points at the end of the sixth round.

Name: Takeover
Description:
Takeover is a stock game for 2-6 players using a Piecepack set. Players take turns merging corporations (tiles) to increase either short-term cash gains (value-up coins) or long-term stocks that pay out at the end of the game (suit-up coins). The suit of a tile represents its industry; the value of each tile, along with the number of other tiles in its stack, represents its worth.

The rules are available on the Piecepack Wiki.

Game System

    Piecepack Game System

Name: Silver Isle
Description:
Each player represents a nation of Europe seeking wealth from a newly discovered island during the age of colonial expansion: England, Pirate Confederation, Spain or France. After forming the isle, players move colonist crews (coins) across the isle on foot, or around the coast by sea in a ship (pawn). Crews exploring new land on foot claim new property for their port (null tile), may establish a mine (die), and fight enemy colonists. After a mine is established, crews may mine the site and transport silver (tokens) to their colony or their ship. The ship may transport silver and/or crews around the coast of the isle and to Europe (off board).

Silver Isle is played with a Piecepack set and the rules can be found on the Piecepack Wiki.

Game System

    Piecepack Game System

Name: MotoX
Description:
Pronounced "motocross", this is, as you might expect, a game of racing motorbikes. Using a Piecepack set, the players create a three-dimensional race track with "jump ramps" created by piling coins under tiles in the track. Players roll dice to determine how far they move, but the farther back in the pack you are the more dice you roll. Also unused coins can be used to add more dice to your roll for a turn, or to recover from a wipe-out.

Rules are available on the Piecepack Wiki

Game System

    Piecepack Game System

Name: Matches
Description:
Matches is an easy game that will exercise your memory and deduction, as well as press your luck. It is enjoyable for children and adults, and also plays well with mixed groups of both.

Rules are available on the Piecepack Wiki.

Game System

    Piecepack Game System

Name: Professor Quizzle's Quiz Wizard Trivia
Description:
This is another game that was created in the early 80's to ride the coat tails of the success of Trivial Pursuit.  There is no board, so you have to keep track of your correct answers on the handy included notepad.  The trivia questions are on very looking familiar cards, and each card also has a category associated with it - go figure.

The most interesting thing about the game is the cute little cartoon of Professor Quizzle printed on the otherwise plain box.

Name: Cranium: Édition Québécoise
Description:
Cranium bills itself as the "whole-brain" game.  It borrows from a range of party and parlour games, including charades, Pictionary, trivia, and the like.

Cranium Édition Québécoise is packed with quintessentially Québécoise content (written in French).  Do you think you can hum "When you're in love?" Or, carve a poutine?

Name: Risk 2210 A.D.: Mission Pack
Description:
A deck of cards that adds missions to Risk 2210 (similar in some ways to the way the Mission Deck does in regular Risk).  Cards are color coded (in red, amber, and green) for difficulty and the deck can be altered accordingly.  Included are rules for various ways of incorporating the 20 card deck into the base game.

Here at last we have something that has been sorely lacking from the new game since its initial release. One of the main difficulties that has arisen in the game is the fact that a single game can go on for a very long time, and even with the introduction of the 5 turn limit a single game can still go on for a number of hours. With this brand new pack of twenty mission cards players are once again put back in charge of the game.

Difficulty Gradings:

     Each mission card has been given a difficulty grade as is highlighted in the top right hand corner on the flip side of each card. The cards are graded green - easy, amber - moderate and red - difficult. What this grading means is that players have more control over the length of time that they’ll likely spend playing each game. For example, removing all of the red graded (difficult) mission cards, players can hopefully limit the length of game play. On the other hand, by removing the green graded (easy) mission cards this could theoretically greatly extend the length of play. With the time constraints, it’s up to you to choose which cards to keep and which to leave.


When:

     When should the mission cards be chosen? Depending upon the mission itself some could offer an unfair advantage if they were chosen prior to all initial reinforcements (those placed before bidding for turn order) having been placed on the board. To therefore avoid this, the mission cards should be chosen at random after all initial reinforcements have been placed, but before the first turn order bidding process has taken place. One thing to bare in mind prior to mission selection is to remove any irrelevant destroy ‘x’ cards if not playing with five players.


A Matter of Points:

     Although there are no set rules as to how players should play with this set of missions cards, here are a few suggestions as to how they can be used to enhance game play. 


* Players can choose to work on the basis of a one mission win i.e. as soon as one mission is completed then the player completing that mission has won.
    * Alternatively, a game could be played on a points basis with each grade of mission being awarded points i.e red = 3, amber = 2 and green = 1, and each game having a pre-agreed points target. Once that target has been reached through the completion of missions then you have a winner.

Players are actively encouraged to play around with the mission rules as best fits their own situations.

Expands:


     Risk 2210 A.D.

Name: Risk 2210 A.D.: Aerial Assault Command Deck
Description:
Introduces a new Aerial Commander to Risk 2210 along with a corresponding deck of Command cards.  According to Insurgency Gaming,

"Each of these new commanders, once brought into play, allows the player who owns them to fly a Sortie at the beginning of each of their turns prior to making a standard attack.  
FLYING A SORTIE 
Each sortie flight takes part in three of distinct stages:
1. Outbound Flight
2. Bombing
3. Return Flight "

Purchase price includes two Aerial commanders and the 20 card deck.

Card distribution:

3 x Propaganda

3 x Resurrection 
3 x phoenix 
3 x Storm Troopers

2 x Kamikaze  
2 x Aerial Assault 
2 x Air Raid 
1 x Dark Angel

RULES:

Aerial Command Token:

     The major change brought with the Aerial Assault command deck is the introduction of the new Aerial Commander. Unlike previous expansion decks, the Aerial Assault deck comes with two neutral colored commanders in order to slot directly into game play as and when required. Each of these new commanders, once brought into play, allows the player who owns then to fly a Sortie at the beginning of each of their turns prior to making a standard attack. At any point where the Aerial commander is not flying a sortie it may be moved like any other commander and also receives the standard d8 defensive dice.


Flying A Sortie:
Each sortie flight takes part in three distinct stages:

1. Outbound Flight - player rolls a d6 dice to establish the maximum amount of territories the Aerial Commander may fly and moves the commander accordingly. The Commander can move between neighboring territories up to the value on the dice - movement may include both land and water territories even if they are controlled by another player. Once the commander has come to the end of its outbound flight the controlling player may choose to commence bombing, this need not be the case if the commander comes to rest in a territory they control.
    * In such a case the controlling player may simply choose to finish the sortie here leaving the commander in place within that territory.

2. Bombing - once the Aerial commander has come to rest above an enemy territory the controlling player should roll a d6 dice and follow the appropriate action dependent upon the number rolled...
    * 1 & 2 Plane is hit by flak. STOP ATTACK. Aerial commander receives half d6 roll on return flight.
    * 3 MISS. Commander may continue bombing.
    * 4, 5 & 6 HIT. Destroy one army in the territory being bombed. Bombing may continue. A maximum of threee armies may be destroyed in this fashion before making the return flight.

3. Return Flight - player rolls a d6 dice to establish the maximum amount of territories the Aerial Commander can move baring in mind any reductions in movement caused by flak damage in the Bombing phase. If the Aerial commander cannot return to a land territory owned by the same player or if it ends its flight above a water territory then it crashes and is destroyed. Once the sortie has ended then that player may continue with the normal run of play.

Additional Aerial Commanders:

     Although only two Aerial Commanders are supplied with the Aerial Assault deck, additional commanders can be obtained from Insurgency Gaming. These additional commanders may be bought by any player during the normal purchase phase of play for the standard price paid for commanders and then placed accordingly. 


What if There’s More Than Two Players:

      Due to the fact that the Aerial Assault deck is originally only provided with two Aerial commanders instead of the five that would ultimately be needed for all players to use them, this is where the two Aerial Assault cards included within the deck come into play, and where their inclusion or exclusion from the deck become of paramount importance. 



     In the case where only two Aerial commander tokens are available, by playing with standard rules, this would mean that the first two players to obtain the commanders would then have sole use of the Aerial command deck and this have a hugely unfair advantage over the other players. 



     In order to rectify this, if only two Aerial commander tokens are available, then the Aerial command deck becomes open to all players from the beginning of the game regardless of whether or not a player controls an Aerial commander. Please note that sorties can and only be carried out through the use of Aerial commanders and, in this case, these can only be brought into play through the respective Aerial Assault cards within the deck. 



     If there are enough Aerial commanders for all players then the Aerial Assault cards should be removed from the deck. This means that the purchase of Aerial commanders now falls into line with the standard rules. Please note, in such an instance the Aerial Assault deck is now only open to those players with Aerial commanders in play. 


Expands:


     Risk 2210 A.D.

Name: Ley Lines
Description:
Ley Lines is played with a Piecepack Set and Dominoes. It was an entry in the LudicSynergy contest.

Each player is the head of an ancient druidic order, building geographic conduits, called ley lines (dominoes), through which mystic energy can be channeled from the sources of such energy, called cairns (coins), to the order's sacred druidic stronghold, a tor (pawn). Each suit represents a different druidic order: worshipers of the sun (suns), worshipers of the moon (moons), worshipers of mankind (crowns), and worshipers of nature (arms).

Rules can be found on the Piecepack Wiki.

Game System

    Piecepack Game System

Name: Fujisan
Description:
Four Shinto priests have traveled from their various prefectures in pilgrimage to the top of Mount Fuji. You must find pathways for them to move up and down the mountain until they can all achieve the summit. Often, this will require you to guide them into positions from which they can assist each other.

Rules can be found on Piecepack Wiki

Game System

    Piecepack Game System

Name: Dungeon Crawl
Description:
After building the dungeon, players move their characters (pawns) around the dungeon seeking treasure (crown coins). Monstrous denizens (moon coins) and deadly traps (sun coins) pose hazards which may cause damage (value-up coins in players' holdings), but defeating these challenges earns experience useful for later encounters (suit-up coins in players' holdings). Players may also attack each other in an attempt to steal treasure or equipment (arms coins). Once the final treasure has been found, the game ends,and the player with the highest total value in treasure wins.

Rules can be found on the Piecepack Wiki.

Game System

    Piecepack Game System

Name: San Andreas
Description:
The big one is coming! Don't wall in the Pacific Ocean.

Players place coins to establish cities and roll dice to determine when quakes will happen. Tiles will shift and cities will be destroyed. If your cities are closer to the Ocean at game end you'll have the most valuable property and win the game.

Rules can be found on the Piecepack Wiki.

Game System

    Piecepack Game System

Name: Silben-Rallye
Description:
From the rules:
"In a playful way, the players together broaden their vocabulary, practice the structure of syllables and the rhythm of words.
...
Whoever is imaginative and eloquent in describing the motifs on the picture cards, will be the first to collect four different postcards.
...
Lets start with the zippy tour straight across Europe! The children travel by train, car, plane or boat and try to visit, as quickly as possible, four of five European capitals in order to collect postcards. It is however not so easy to move on as it doesn’t depend just on throwing the dice. Only the one who carefully looks at the pictures and proves to have enough imagination in describing them, will reach their aim."

Name: Back to Blighty
Description:
Back to Blighty is a diceless card game, which is played mainly with 4 decks of terrain cards and a player sheet.

Your plane is shot down over enemy occupied France and you manage to find a French family but you cannot stay there too long you must find the safe house.

6 different pilots with different characteristics to choose from 12 different routes that must be followed. You have 4 different terrain types, Countryside, road, river and railway. Traveling by night you pick a relevant card which has a distance and time these are moved along a track. The longer you are out the more tired you become, but you must find somewhere to rest before daylight comes. some cards are German soldiers but these may be avoided if the conditions are right, if you are challenged I hope your language skills are up to scratch and that the 6 days in the outdoors isn't going to give you away.

Tactical decisions include how long into the morning are you prepared to travel before you find somewhere to rest for the day, balance this with how good will you be if you were challenged by a German soldier. How far you have to travel before your safe compared to the fact the more days your out the more disheveled you look and therefor more suspicious.

Other things included are crossing rivers, swimming, boat, or bridge, weather which may change half way through the night. The heavier the rain the less likely you will be challenged but the less rest you will get. Going into a town to seek resistance members but beware the Gestapo and German sympathizers. Stamina, food, blending in, stealing a German soldiers push-bike all take a role.

Name: The Lone Tank
Description:
The game is set during World War Two, where you are a German tank commander who has to get his battle-worn tank safely back to friendly faces. The only way back is through a small village, but this contains elements of enemy infantry.

It is a card driven game, and there are two types of card. Terrain cards, which is the pack you are trying to go through as quickly as possible, where the last card is always the Bridge card. There are also Event cards which mainly contain enemy soldiers. Each card has an activation number, the activation level is decided by shuffling activation cards into the Terrain deck. So the further into the village you go the more likely you are to meet enemy opposition.

You give orders to your crew, spending order points. Example: prepare main tank gun, load main tank gun, move turret, observe etc. Your tank creates noise which attracts enemy soldiers and the terrain you move over may also have a bearing on this as well.

Combat is a series of dice rolls, not everyone's favourite part of the game but most wargamers will be okay with this. Also included are the use of Schürzen (side skirts), Zimmerit paste, PIAT attacks, a Sherman, and tank traps.

Name: Grashüpfer im Zahlenland
Description:
From the rules:
"Once upon a time there was a land of numbers.
The inhabitants counted everything they saw. They knew that there was one sun, three hills and twelve sunflowers. However there came the day when they had counted everything that could be counted in the land of numbers, and they became very sad.

That's when the little grasshopper remembered an arithmetic game his grandfather used to play with him. He invited the inhabitants in the land of numbers to play with him. So they competed with the little grasshopper, counting and jumping.
Up until today this is the favorite game of all the inhabitants in the land of numbers.

Dear Parents and Educators:
The game Grasshopper in the land of numbers combines, in a playful way, the physical activity with the learning of numbers. The games stimulate motor skills and acquaint the children, depending on their age and the variation chosen, with the numbers 1 to 10. For children a little older they offer a first approach to adding and subtracting. For the games, it is not always important that there is a winner. Children often have fun resolving a task together."

Name: Subway Run
Description:
A card game from Korea in which you play a subway inspector.  Rules in Korean, but cards seem to be mostly language independent once you learn the meaning of their symbols. Cards are circular.

Comes with 66 route cards, 18 action cards, 1 die, 1 set of instructions, 1 tin circular case.  Ages 8 and up.

Name: Magistratvm
Description:
Welcome to the Roman Republic! The aim of the game is to win political control of the Republic. The two areas of play are the Provinces in the electoral circuit and the Offices. Players will place influence tokens in the Provinces in the hope of winning provincial elections which provide influence. Magistrates and Governors also provide influence, and can be used to take special actions which will help players defeat their rivals. The game ends once all 24 Provinces have been decided, in which case the player with the most influence from both the Provinces and the Offices wins.

Equipment Needed:
a) 1 standard piecepack;
b) about $2 in change to represent gold (ideal breakdown would be 50 x 1c, 10 x 5c, 10 x 10c;
c) cubes in 4 different colors to use as influence markers (20 per player);
d) a printout of the Table of Offices from the rules

Rules can be found on the Piecepack Wiki.

Game System

    Piecepack Game System

Name: Queen's Gate
Description:
Queen's Gate is a vehicle to bring licensed characters into Queen's Blade's world.  Queen's Gate includes some well-known characters and character designers.  Like Queen's Blade, it is also licensed from the Lost Worlds system, and completely compatible with any Lost Worlds book.  As usual, it is primarily a one-on-one game, in which each player must have a book representing a character.  The players swap books, so that each sees how his opponent reacts to his decisions.

The Lost Worlds system uses a much more complex version of rock-paper-scissors, in that both players blindly select an action, hoping to second-guess each other and score a hit.

Part of the Lost Worlds series of books.
Families: Series: Picture Book Games (Nova Game Designs)

Name: The Seven Years War & The War of Austrian Succession
Description:
The Seven Years War & The War of Austrian Succession  is an area movement game of these two conflicts.

The game system uses the simple RISK method of combat:  highest roll with a twist, cards are not areas conquered but are events that can give the player an advantage or create a disadvantage for an opponent.  Cards offer extra troops, use of neutrals, generals, force an opponent out of the conflict, ect.

Number of players can run from 2 to 7 allowing for much diplomacy between players.

Game is available through Calumet Armchair Wargamers at RB1863@Yahoo.com
Families: History: War of the Austrian Succession

Name: War Between the States
Description:
The War Between the States is a basic rendition of the conflict in the United States between 1861 and 1865.

The 22" x 34" board covers the area of conflict.
Using a simple combat system of highest die roll, this game offers a twist:  cards are gained by successful combat between players and the cards gained offer players advantages or create disadvantages for the opponent.

Two to six people may play allowing for inter side conflict as to offensives, reinforcements, etc.

Victory is determined by occupying the 5 major cities of the South by April 1865.

Name: I Win
Description: Educational game for teaching elementary math. A player starts by taking a face up card or one from the deck. The player then checks his hand for any matching pairs to form a complete and correct simple arithmetic equation. These pairs are placed face up on the table, and the player then discards one card. The game continues until one player rids his hand of all pairs.

Name: Madicken
Description:
Astrid Lindgren is one of Swedens' most famous writers of childrens books. This game is from one of her books that has become a film.

Madicken likes pretzels and in this game it's three different kinds of pretzels. On the back of the pretzel there is a number and you   move forward this number of steps to try to be the first to the finish line were a giant pretzel is waiting for you that Abbe made.

Contents:
1 board game
4 playing pieces
45 pretzel cards
1 giant pretzel

Name: Kracht van 8 Kaartspel
Description:
The cards in this game show situations from the daily life of young kids. Each card has a short, positive message. With the 42 cards, 8 different games can be played.
By playing these games, the children will learn to treat each other (and themselves) with respect.

Name: Ultra Fight
Description:
Get in the ring and win!
Ultra Fight is fast 2 player game.
Players take on a role of one of 23 fighters cards of different martial arts (tae-kwon-do, judo, kung-fu, boxing, karate, sumo...). Players try to choose smart between 8 action cards and win by knock-out or submission or there will be "judges" decision-on points. This is first game designed and illustrated by Sven Nemet.
There are also two scoring boards and 6 cards that gives you plus points.

Name: King's Progress
Description:
Medieval Kings would often visit the various cities of their kingdoms in order to enforce tax collection and discourage thoughts of rebellion and treason. This was known as a Progress. In this game each player acts as a King’s chancellor
overseeing the King’s Progress throughout the cities of the kingdom. The aim is to collect the most tax at the end of the game by steering your own King through the richest cities with the highest investments while scheming to force the Kings of your opponents to travel through poor cities with low investments.

Rules can be found on the Piecepack Wiki.

Game System

    Piecepack Game System

Name: Octacompass
Description: Octacompass is a two-player strategy game that uses an eight-sided die to determine which direction your pieces can move.  The die is labeled with the 8 directions of the compass which determines the direction your piece can move.  You can 'bounce' piece off the edges of the board allowing for much more flexibility in controlling your piece movements.  Octacompass is a mix of strategy and probability which makes for a truly unique two-player gaming experience.

Name: Flip-Flop
Description: A tile turning game in which players attempt find the fewest moves that will result in turning all tiles in a 3x3 grid to a to  a particular side. Each tile has a different power, which may be used in flipping other tiles, so careful planning and sequencing of tile flips is the key to winning.  Similar to Ricochet Robots, players study the layout and make bids about how many moves it will take to reach a solution. Players score points by successfully reaching a solution in light of others' bids.

Name: 40K Skirmish
Description: A game based on the Warhammer 40K universe. It is played with miniature figures, each representing one combatant, on an 8x8 grid (a chess or checkers board may be used). The object is to destroy all opposing units. The players purchase their units from force lists which describe the units of the Space Marines and the Tyranid/Genestealer Brood. Units are rated for hit points, movement, and armor. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck. Card play determines how the combatants move and attack.

Name: 38th Parallel
Description:
A two-player card game set in the Korean War. One player is the U.N., the other is the Communists. Each hand the players are dealt eight cards (Logistics Phase), after which they can discard and redraw up to four (Deployment Phase), and then the players reveal their offensive and defensive cards (Attack Phase). After resolving the interaction of the cards played in the Attack Phase, the hand is scored and the player with the highest card total wins the hand.

A player wins the war by winning three hands in a row. If neither player does so after ten hands, the war is a tie. However, there is an Atomic Bomb card which ends the game immediately when drawn, at which point victory is determined by the draw of a final card, unless the Communist player is able to negate the Atomic Bomb with a Limited War card.

Name: Ancient Wargames Rules
Description:
A set of Ancient Wargame Rules designed for use with 15mm or 25mm figures.

Infantry, cavalry and camels are on a ratio of 1 figure per 20 actual troops.

Elephants, chariots, transport and artillery pieces are on a scale on 1 model per 8 actual pieces.

The set of rules is closely aligned with the set released by Wargames Research Group (WRG). Action is based on an Igo/Ugo system, without the need for written orders.

Name: Pas de CHARGE!
Description:
Pas de Charge is a set of rules for Napoleonic Miniatures. It is designed with the idea of recreating divisional and corps level battles during the period 1800 to 1815. It utilizes a figure scale of 1 model equaling 30 actual troops.

The game is based on the simultaneous movement concept. In order to achieve this, it is necessary to write orders. As a result, the sequence of play is as follows:

Phase 1- Order writing
Phase 2-Charges are announced
Phase 3-Counter charges are announced
Phase 4-Movement
Phase 5-Fire
Phase 6-Melee
Phase 7-Morale checks

The rules contain a section on organization and mounting of figures for the main combatants of the era.

A card game based on the exploits of James Bond, Agent 007, where you compete to become the top agent by acquiring Plot and Villain cards with a higher total Danger Level than those of the other players. A special minor victory is awarded to the player ending up with the most cards in his Seduction Pile. The game features specific card sets for Dr. No, From Russia With Love, Goldfinger, Thunderball.

Name: Släpp fram mig!!
Description:
This is a childrens game. Your job is to get both your boat and your car to the finish-line before your opponent does. Will the bridge be open for your boat or the car? Happy racing.

Contents:
1 board game
2 bridges
1 usual dice
1 symbolic dice
8 playing pieces
4 tull marker

Name: Anera's Arena uitbreiding #1
Description:
This expansion for Anera's Arena adds ranged attacks and magic to the game.

Two new attributes are added to the characters:
- Magic Points, that together with Movement Points may be used to cast spells
- Magic Resistance, that measures the chance a character can resist a spell.

Four new characters are added to the game:

The Elf - Armed with a bow, the Elf attack up to four spaces away. He has a spell that allows him to shoot faster.

The Halfling - The Halfling can throw stones (up to two squares). A hit will cause the opponent to fall.

The Orc - When the Orc hits with an attack, he may make a second attack.

The Mage - The Mage has several spells available in the game: A Fireball and a Stab of Pain to damage an opponent, Heal/Repair to heal someone or repair armor, Forced Movement to move an opponent and Double Pillar to double the movement speed of a pillar.

Expands:

    Anera's Arena

Name: Monopoly: Pirates of the Caribbean Trilogy Edition
Description:
Yo ho, it’s a pirate’s life for YOU as buy, sell and trade key haunts and pirate hangouts from all three Pirates of the Caribbean movies: Curse of the Black Pearl, Dead Man’s Chest and At World’s End. The adventure continues as your favorite scurvy pirates return to battle and vie for ultimate control of the high seas in this Pirates of the Caribbean Trilogy Edition of the world’s most popular board game, MONOPOLY. Set sail for exotic ports and infamous locales, including Rumrunner’s Isle, Tia Dalma’s Shack and the Chamber of the Brethren Court. The fate of the seven seas lies in your hands now, matey. Do you have what it takes to outwit, outlast and outplay the legendary Pirates of the Caribbean? Argh, properly warned, ye be, says I.

Six collectible pewter tokens include Jack’s Shrunken Head, Davy Jones’ Heart, Flying Dutchman Cannon, Davy Jones’ Dice Cup, Jack Sparrow’s Hat and Davy Jones’ Locket.

Name: Monopoly: Denver Broncos
Description: It’s Mile High Magic! The Denver Broncos™ and the world’s most popular board game, MONOPOLY, have huddled up to create the ultimate Broncos gridiron fantasy for fans ages 8 and above. Join up to five of your friends as you buy, sell and trade the greatest Broncos of all time, including John Elway, Terrell Davis, Jake Plummer, and Rod Smith. With six collectible pewter tokens, including the legendary Barrel Man, lead your franchise on “the Drive” to the Super Bowl.

Name: Monopoly: Chicago Cubs
Description: The MONOPOLY game partners with Major League Baseball® to bring you the ultimate collector’s edition of the MONOPOLY game featuring the Chicago Cubs™. Compete to own the Cubs greatest assets including Hall of Famers like Billy Williams and Hack Wilson, all-time greats like Fergie Jenkins, Carlos Zambrano, Aramis Ramirez and the 1907 World Series Championship. Current stars like Alfonso Soriano, Derrek Lee, Michael Barrett, Ted Lilly and pieces of Wrigley Field™ including the Marquee, the Scoreboard and the Ivy are up for grabs! Includes six collectible pewter tokens for the true baseball fan - Cubs baseball cap, pitcher, batter, hotdog, ball in glove and catcher's mask. This game, like no other, encompasses the best of the Cubs.

Name: Monopoly: My Fantasy Drivers
Description:
The world’s best selling board game and NASCAR’s top drivers team up and put you in charge. For the first time ever YOU decide the layout of the MONOPOLY® game board. With 30 removable and reusable driver labels to choose from, like Matt Kenseth, Jeff Gordon and Kurt Busch, there are over ONE BILLION possible driver lineups! Who gets Boardwalk? Which driver will you put on Park Place? It’s decision time and you get to choose!

Includes 30 removable and reusable driver labels and six custom tokens: headset, RV, war wagon, gasman, racecar and the checkered flag.

Name: Monopoly: San Antonio Spurs
Description: The San Antonio Spurs dynasty and America’s favorite board game team up to bring you this collector’s edition of the MONOPOLY game. Buy, sell and trade the greatest players from the Spurs dynasty including David Robinson, Tim Duncan, Sean Elliot, Manu Ginobili, George Gervin, and Tony Parker. Use one of the six collectible pewter tokens, including the Spur, Basketball Hoop, NBA basketball, NBA Championship Trophy, player shooting and defensive player to race around the board. Vie to own each of the team’s NBA Championships.

Name: Monopoly: St. Louis Cardinals World Series
Description:
The MONOPOLY Brand proudly presents the St. Louis Cardinals World Series Collector’s Edition. The St. Louis Cardinal’s soared in 2006 as they took home their 10th World Series Championship title.

Some of the greatest moments in playoff history including Yadier Molina’s game winning homerun and Adam Wainright’s strike out against the Mets™ in game seven are immortalized in this collector’s edition. Buy, sell, and trade players like Albert Pujols, Scott Spiezio, Juan Encarnacion, and Jeff Weaver in this classic game of risk taking and deal making. Use one of six collectible pewter tokens, including the World Series trophy, batter, pitcher, ball in glove, hot dog and catcher’s mask, to round the bases as you relive the magic of the 2006 Fall Classic. Now fans can celebrate the Cardinals first championship of the 21st century.

Name: Air War Europe
Description:
“Basic Simulation of the Air War component of WWII. Victory: There are two ways to win: Reduce your opponent to zero Production Points. Accumulate twice the Strategy Tokens of your opponent.”

The game is played with three types of cards - a Mission Deck, an Event Deck, and Plane Decks (with unique cards for each player, Allied and Luftwaffe). Players set up attack missions against their adversary and attempt to intercept incoming attack missions. Strategy Tokens are received for successfully completing Ground Support Missions.

Name: Alien Conspiracy
Description: Players control one of eight competing Alien Factions, each of which has a Special Ability.  The players receive a varying assort of Action Tokens each turn. These Tokens may be spent to draw cards, put Faction members into play, and roll on the Intrigue table. Players gain Influence Points by controlling Faction members and Plot cards. The winner is the first player to gain 100 Influence Points.

Name: Hannibal Ante Portas
Description:
Game about 2nd Punic War.

Strategic-operational scale: units are infantry, cavalry, elephants and navy, 1 day per game turn. Battles are played on separate board.
Each month is economical phase: players gain taxes from hold towns and spend them for upkeep and recruitment of forces.

Probably this game was an inspiration for Robert Zak to create his game Hannibal Barkas almost 15 years later.

Name: MoonDragon
Description:
MoonDragon is a game consisting of fourteen hand-painted stones. The stones represent two dragons, each consisting of seven parts: a head, two wings and four legs.

Both players control one dragon, and try to chase the other dragon away from the moon. The fight involves taking up complicated stances, which should protect your dragon's vulnerable areas while allow him to bite your opponent's dragon. These stances can get quite complicated, for example: your head between your right wing and a hind leg, while your front legs are over your left wing.

Name: Soccer Action Packed Dice Game
Description:
Off-the-field fun for players. Roll the dice to see if you hit a corner kick, made the goal, got a penalty kick, etc. Fast-paced dice game with four dice, a small duffel/carry bag and score sheet. For one or more players.

Features
Includes set of offensive and a set of defensive dice
Mini black duffel bag storage case 
Ages 6 and up 
1-2 Players

Also included are instructions as to what the die rolls mean and how to score based on the die results.

Name: Nummerett
Description: 2 players roll dices and try to get their pawns out on the playing board. The two players have their own side of the board. When a pawn is out there it can be moved one line further, if the player is successful with the dices. The aim of the game is to manage to place all pawns on the line in the middle of the playing board.

Name: Mindgammon
Description:
Game description from the publisher:

Created by a backgammon champion, Mindgammon captures the essence of the original "backgammon", but it's different.

Game description by a BG Geek:

Mindgammon is most closely related to the Backgammon variant Acey-Duecy, where all 15 men start off the board and must be entered into the first 6 points (playing spaces) before the game can progress further.  Also a roll of 1-2, once played, is followed by a second move for that player.  Mindgammon has also taken elements of Old English Backgammon in that you are limited to 6 men per point.

The classic board is now laid out in a single column, making the game visually easier for beginners.  Bearing-off is by exact count only.  Also there are penalties for "unsportsmanlike" rolling of the dice, either out-of-turn or out-of-bounds.

Name: Pharaoh's Heir
Description:
The setting is ancient Egypt. Pharaoh is dying, and, in a break from tradition, has decided that he will name an heir who will best serve Egypt's interests rather than hand the nation over to his handsome but rather dim-witted first-born son. Each player is the leader of a powerful Egyptian Noble Family with the ambition to rise to the level of Pharaoh. Rival Families will provide stiff competition, and all will have to contend with the force of nature that dictates the pattern of Egyptian life -- the River Nile. In flood the Nile can provide increased harvests but may also damage structures, whereas severe drought will cause starvation and suffering.

Pharaoh has issued several decrees. He demands a great harvest, sufficient people to build yet another mighty monument to himself upon his death (most likely a pyramid, although occasionally the Pharaohs preferred big cat-like things), as well as in increase in the worship of (read: sacrifice to) his favorite gods. In return for excelling in these areas of ancient Egyptian life, Pharaoh is willing to make you his heir. Oh, yes, one last thing -- Pharaoh also rewards the Families that develop the most valuable buildings and the most desirable land districts...

Rules can be found on the Piecepack Wiki.

Game System

    Piecepack Game System

Name: Fifth Element
Description: A card game based on the movie of the same name. One player represents the side of Good, the other the side of Evil. The players draw a hand of eight cards which feature characters and elements from the movie. After discarding and redrawing up to four cards, the players compare their hands and the player whose cards have the highest total wins. The first player to win three hands in a row wins the game.

Name: Star Wars, A New Hope
Description:
“Luke, Han and Leia need to get back to the Millennium Falcon in the Death Star’s Docking  Bay. But Vader and his minions are in hot pursuit.”

The game is played on the map from the Escape From the Death Star miniature game, or the players may design a custom map. The object of the game is to destroy all of your opponent’s characters. Each player controls three characters. The Rebel player plays Luke Skywalker, Princess Leia, and Han Solo. The Empire player plays Darth Vader, an anonymous Stormtrooper, and (from the Episode III cutting room floor?) Boba Fett.
Each character has a deck of cards containing a specific number of Power, Toughness, and Force cards in allocations intended to represent the relative abilities of the characters. These cards are used to resolve combat. Movement of the characters is determined by drawing Area cards.

Name: Advanced Culture & Conquest
Description: A card game based on the rise of ancient civilizations. The cards represent Advancements, Cities, Leaders, Wonders, and Events. The players build Cities and Wonders, establish trade (to gain Advancements held by opponents), and start wars. The possibility of catastrophic events always looms in the background. The object of the game is to have the most Victory Points after the deck has been gone through twice.

Name: Advanced Star Frontiers Lensman
Description:
“In this game you play a Lensman Ranger with his intergalactic assault scout ship. You must use your Lensman Powers to undermine enemy bases while battling any Morad ships that you encounter . . . When you have successfully infiltrated and brought down all four Morad quadrant bases in the Second Galaxy, you win.”

This solitaire game is played by randomly selecting cards from a deck containing a variety of Morad ships (frigates, destroyers, and cruisers) and four “Quadrent Base” cards. You must defeat each ship until you have encountered and successfully infiltrated all four bases. Each ship is rated for power, hull strength, number of weapons/attacks, and weapon strength.

Name: Adventure Club
Description:
“Players are modern-day, rich, athletic, leisure-minded adventurers.”

The players choose one of three traits for their adventurer: “World Class Athlete”, “Filthy Rich”, or “No Responsibilities.” The players collect and play resource cards allowing them to complete adventures such as “Running of the Bulls”, “Sahara Marathon”, “Ski the South Pole”, and “Suborbital Space Flight.”

The game ends when there are no Adventure cards left, at which point the player with the highest Victory Point total wins.

Name: Adventurers
Description:
A game of archaeological adventuring set in the 1930’s and 1940’s. Save the damsel, defeat the villain, and recover the ancient artifact before your adversaries can!

The players choose their adventurer type from a variety of professions, such as Archaeologist, Daredevil Pilot, Occult Expert, Private Investigator, or Soldier of Fortune. Each profession confers a special benefit.

Through drawing and playing cards, the players conduct research, travel to exotic locations, acquire weapons and other useful items, and attempt to escape dangerous encounters.

To win the game, be the first player to visit five locations, the last of which must be an Ancient location, which represents the successful recovery of the ancient relic.

Name: Adventures in Talislanta
Description: A fantasy adventure boardgame based on the Talislanta role-playing game. The game is played on a randomly constructed map made out of an 11x11 array of map tiles. Each player randomly chooses a character from a deck of around forty character cards. The players journey around the map, facing deadly encounters, and attempt to complete adventures (tests of strength). If a player’s character is killed, a new character is drawn and the player continues the game with that character. The object of the game is to be the first player to successfully complete five adventures.
Families: Versions & Editions: Board Game Versions of Role-Playing Games

Name: Adventures in Wonderland
Description: A card game for two or more players based on the book “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland” by Lewis Carroll. The game is played using a deck containing Character Cards, Location Cards, Action Cards, and Modifier Cards. The object of the game is to wake up the opposing players by increasing their Insanity Totals. In addition to the standard set of cards, the rules provide a second set of cards based on “Through the Looking Glass.”

Name: Afrika Korps
Description:
From the deigner :
“Simulation of the North Africa campaign of WWII. 
Card game for two players.
One player is the Germans (& Italians), the other player is the Commonwealth (British & Allies).”

Each game turn consists of three phases. In the Logistics Phase, the players draw a hand of cards (the number drawn by each player varies from six to eight depending on the stage of the war). In the Strategy Phase, the players may discard up to three cards and draw replacements. In the Battle Phase, the players reveal their hands and the player with the highest Force point total wins the hand and takes a Terrain Token from the loser.

Each player starts the game with three Terrain Tokens. The game ends when one player controls all six Terrain Tokens.

Name: SanQuest
Description:
Subtitel: Een bloedfanatiek spel

A race game were you roll the dice, move and have to answer questions about blood in 4 categories.

Sanquin is a Blood Supply foundation http://www.sanquin.nl/sanquin-eng/sqn_home_eng.nsf

Name: AFV
Description:
“A two-player card game of modern tank combat. Each player starts the game with 16 AFV (Armored Fighting Vehicle) Tokens. Reduce your opponent to 0 AFV tokens.”

Each player starts with a hand of ten cards drawn from a common deck. The card types include Offensive Attack, Defensive Attack, Units, Weapons, Movement, Obstacle, Protection, Leadership, Morale, and Reconnaissance. Each turn has 8 phases: Deploy Phase, Leadership Phase, Reconnaissance Phase, Defensive Phase, Defensive Movement Phase, Offensive Phase, Offensive Movement Phase, and Redeploy Phase.

In order to win the game, a player must play cards to mount successful attacks which result in the opponent's loss of AFV tokens.

Name: AFV Skirmish
Description:
“Two Player Board & Card Game of Modern Tank Combat. Victory: Destroy all enemy Armored Fighting Vehicle Units.  Units: Each player starts the game with 8 AFV (Armored Fighting Vehicle) Units. Use Miniatures, counters, or tokens to represent AFV’s. Each Unit represents a combined arms squadron.”

The play of the cards is central to the game, as the cards control when the AFV's can move, attack, and defend.

Name: Age of Industry
Description:
“A card game for 2 to 4 players, or more. Each player controls a country during the First Industrial Revolution. Players try to develop their economies as quickly as possible.” The game is played with two sets of cards, an Industry Deck and an Event Deck.

There are seven categories of “Resources” that are tracked for each country: Food, Population (Skilled and Unskilled Labor), Fossil Fuels, Steel (Production Capacity), Transportation, Guns, and Luxury Goods (Peacetime Consumption). Each country begins with an equal amount of resources.

“The first player to have a combined score of 100+ in Guns and Luxury Goods wins. If more than 1 person gets 100+ on the same turn, the Player with the higher score wins. If it is still tied, use Transportation, and then Population, as tie-breakers.”

Name: Agea
Description:
“Greek Heroes undertake adventures of Mythic proportions. Players accumulate Heroes, City States, Relics, and great Victories over legendary monsters with the aid of the Gods. To play you will have to make your own cards. There are 129 cards in the deck.”

The object of the game is to accumulate the most Victory Points. Victory Points are acquired by controlling Heroes and City States, owning Relics, winning Wars, holding Blessing cards, and successfully completing Challenges.

Name: Air Fare
Description:
A bidding card game in which the players control airlines. The object is to have the most money at the end of the game.

The game is played using a custom deck consisting of 110 cards of three different types: Planes, Landing Rights, and Events. Landing Rights cards are also called Terminals. Also required for play are a ten-sided die and a paper and pen to record profits (or play money may be used to represent profits instead).

Each player starts the game with 50 million dollars, one Boeing 737 or one McDonnell Douglas DC-9, and landing rights to two Minor Airports. The game ends when there are no cards left in the deck.

Name: Air Tac
Description:
A game of modern jet fighter dogfighting for two players. Each player starts with two jets: a leader and a wingman. You win the game by shooting your opponent’s planes out of the air.

The game uses a custom deck of over 150 cards which regulate movement and combat. The game may be played on a chess board or any other 8x8 grid. Also required for play are six-sided dice, miniature airplanes that fit within the squares of the board, and counters to keep track of missiles and damage.

Name: Air to Air
Description:
“Two player card game simulating modern Jet Fighter Air Combat. Objective: Kill all of your opponent’s planes. Setup: In the standard game each side has 2 planes: A flight leader and his wingman. For a quick game play one-on-one. A dogfight involving many planes is referred to as a Furball. Use coins or dice to keep track of planes.”

The game is played using a deck of seven different types of cards: Pilot, Initiative, Tactics (Team), Maneuver, Attack, Defense, and Kill. The players attempt to play a superior number of Maneuver and Attack cards, and ultimately score a kill with a Kill card.

Name: Airship Adventures
Description:
“Players control fanciful Victorian Airships used to complete various Missions around the Globe. Background: The year is 1850 and Airships rule the Skies! Victory: The first player to accumulate 20 Victory Points is the winner.” Victory Points are lost or gained based on how successfully Missions are completed.

Each player controls an Airship which has six basic traits: Military, Exploration, Diplomacy, Transportation, Rescue, and Speed. Attachment and Crew cards help improve various traits. Each airship starts with five randomly drawn Crew cards and Attachment cards. The Crew cards represent exceptional people aboard the Airship. The Attachment cards represent Weapons, Tools, Rooms, and Equipment built into the Airship.

Components: Three decks of cards (Mission Deck, Crew Deck, and Attachment Deck) and two ten-sided dice.

Name: Mahlzeit!
Description:
"Feed me!" the little yellow seal begs the zoo keeper.
"No, feed me first – I’m much more hungry!" the green seal whines.
And at once all four seals open their mouth and start howling. Desperately the zoo keeper looks from one seal to the other – which one should he feed first? A smart idea occurs to him; "Lets play a game together.Whoever wins, gets a fish!"
"Hurray, playing games is fun!" the seals cheer and flap their flippers. Impatiently they wait for the game to start.

Game 1. Feeding the Seals
Roll the die. If a colored seal appears either open or close it's mouth (on the game board). If a fish appears, and the corresponding seal's mouth is open, feed it. The game ends as soon as a player has fed a seal with their last fish.

Game 2. No, no – I Don’t Like Fish!
This is a variant of Go Fish, but with the fish tiles and the open mouthed seals on the board.

Game 3. I want fish!
As in Game #1 but each players has a secret seal (color) identity. When feeding a seal, if your color's mouth is closed, you must feed someone else's seal. The player whose seal has eaten the most fish wins.

Name: Suspect Behavior
Description: Suspect Behavior is a free party game by Tim Denee. One player is the inspector and the others are the suspects. Each suspect wrights down who he or she thinks did it and then the investigator questions each suspect until he or she knows who did it.

Name: Siege By Number
Description:
A tactical battle game for up to four players, using tiles to form the gameboard, and coins ("armies") and pawns ("commanders") as playing pieces. Dice are used to determine how far pieces can move, while the coin values determine the outcome of the one-on-one battles that take place in the game. The objective of the game is to move your Commander onto another player’s Home Base tile.

Rules can be found on the piecepack wiki.

Game System

    Piecepack Game System

Name: Sarcophagus
Description:
Each player takes the part of an archaeologist discovering the secrets of one of the great pyramids and its sacred sarcophagus, hoping to gain the most fame by the end of the expedition.

Sarcophagus is played with a piecepack, the tiles are laid in a pyramid shape, with 3 doubled up at the bottom, as players put their influence markers (coins) on the tiles, more of the pyramid is revealed and they have new areas to compete over. Unless you have a god tile to protect you, watch out for the those traps!

Rules are available on the piecepack wiki.

Game System

    Piecepack Game System

Name: Alien Empires
Description:
Alien races with varying powers compete to control twenty worlds. The Alien Race which establishes control over all of the Worlds wins the game.

The card deck used in the game includes three types of cards: Force cards, Race cards, and Event cards. Each player also requires a uniquely colored set of fifty or more Control markers. The game may be played on any hex map with the twenty World markers distributed as the players see fit.

Your quest for galactic conquest starts from the home world of your choice. In addition, you begin the game with three Race cards that define abilities, traits and powers that your alien race will possess throughout the game.

Name: Aliens
Description:
A card game pitting one player’s Colonial Marines versus the other player’s Aliens.

Each player has a deck of 36 cards equally divided into three suits (Combatants, Weapons, and Tactics). Players attempt to build hands with the greatest combat value. When battles are lost, the cards are discarded to a Casualty Pile.

The game ends when all of a player’s cards are in the Casualty Pile, at which point the other player wins the game.

Name: Alpha Centauri
Description:
A card game based on the Sid Meier computer game of the same name.

The game is played with a custom card deck composed of the following types of cards: Events, Technologies, Structures, Special Projects, Landmarks, Proposals, and Social Engineering. Tokens and markers are used to keep track of Bases (cities), Units (military forces), and Credits (income).

Six social factors, also referred to as scores, are tracked for each player’s Faction: Population, Economics, Research, Military, Ecology, and Espionage. These factors are used to determine victory.

There are four types of victory defined in the game: Diplomatic, Economic, Conquest, and Transcendence. The first player to achieve any one of these victory conditions wins the game.

Name: Amber
Description: A card game set in the world of Amber as described in the series of novels by Roger Zelazny. This game depicts nine Princes fighting to control Amber sometime after the disappearance of King Oberon. The game is won by controlling Amber for five consecutive turns, or controlling Amber and capturing or killing all Princes controlled by opposing players.

Name: American Game Hunter
Description: A simple hunting themed card game. The object of the game is to be the first player to make a kill. To do so, a player must acquire two Technique cards and one each of the Weapon, Habitat, Prey, and Spoiler cards.

Name: American Revolution
Description:
“Two player Card game of the American Revolution. One player is the Americans, the other is the British."

"Players share a common deck. The card list has 120+ cards."

"The game is played in 7 Strategic turns corresponding to the 7 years of the war: 1775, 1776, 1777, 1778, 1779, 1780, 1781."

"Victory: The winner is the first player to win 3 turns in a row, or if this does not occur, the player to win turn 1781. (It’s not how many battles you won, it’s who won the last battle.)”

Name: Amulets
Description:
A fantasy themed multi-player Mastermind style deduction game.

"A (not really) fantasy game of deduction for 3-5 players. Five spirits are captured in five amulets. The wizards try to find out their correct placements on the altar to cast the freeing spell. Succeeding means honour, failure means
eternal doom."

Designer's note: "This game, years old and deriving from boring school times, is nothing else but a master mind clone, but a funky multi-player one.  Experienced players should not need more than 5-6 questions. This is not really a party game, since all players stare at their notes and beg each active player for a thinking break :) - give it a try."

Name: Ancient Battlefields
Description:
“Ancients Wargame with emphasis on Command & Control. Victory: You win if you rout the opposing General.”

Played on a square grid with terrain arranged as desired by the players. The game includes a detailed scenario generation system which allows for randomly determined army quality and composition, and leaders of varying ability (including attributes for “legendary generals.”) The rules also describe special characteristics and/or special units for the Egyptians, Mongols, Greeks, Athenians, Spartans, Persians, Romans, Carthaginians, and Celts.

Name: Ancient Generals
Description: Each player is a general fielding an ancient army represented by the cards in their respective decks. The game includes a deck of 100 cards, composed of 60 Tactics cards and 40 Unit cards. Each player is dealt 50 cards to start the game. The object is to destroy your opponent’s army by causing him to run out of cards. A player loses once he has no more cards left in his deck or reserve pile.

Name: Ancient Skirmish
Description:
“Battle between two Ancient Armies. Bronze Age/Age of the Chariot. Each figure represents a group of 500 men. Victory: You win if you destroy the opposing General or Camp.”

Chits or miniatures are used to represent the combat units. The units come in six types: Heavy Infantry, Light Infantry, Heavy Cavalry, Light Cavalry, General, and Camp.

The game is played on an 8x8 grid (chessboard) representing the battlefield. Each player starts with one unit on each square of his back two rows. Units may not stack.
 There are four custom card decks used in the game: the Infantry Deck, Cavalry Deck, Shock Deck, and Missile Deck. The cards are used to initiate movement and combat, and to defend against attacks.

Name: Ancient Warfare Redux
Description:
“Battle between ancient armies. Each figure represents a general, camp or unit of troops. Victory: You win if you destroy your opponent’s General or 8 of his units. A Camp counts as 2 units.”

Chits or miniatures are used to represent the combat units. The game is played on an 8x8 grid (or chessboard) to represent a small battlefield. Each army consists of  a General, a Camp, and eleven other units. Each player places his units on his back two rows. Units may not stack. The players draw from a deck of cards and use their hand of cards to initiate movement and combat, and to defend against attacks.

Name: Anthill
Description: The players control rival ant colonies. To win the game you must destroy all rival opposing colonies. The game is played on an 8x8 grid, such as a chess board, that represents the backyard of a suburban house. Terrain is randomly placed and consists of sweet spots (food), concrete slabs, dry spots, and covered spots. Each player starts with a colony of ten ants in a corner of the board. A deck of cards is used to resolve combat. Card play also permits a colony to nest to generate more ant units.

Name: Arab Israeli Wars
Description:
“Solo Card Game System simulating the Arab Israeli Wars 1948+. Currently only cards set for the Israeli War of Independence is available.  The player takes the role of the Israelis. Arab deployments are automatic.”

The game is played on three Fronts: the Northern Frontier (Galilee), Central Frontier (Jerusalem), and Southern front (Negev). Each Front is represented by six Territory Tokens, all of which are under the control of the Israelis (the solo player) at the start of the game. If the Arabs are able to acquire control all six tokens on any one Front, you suffer a Complete Loss. If you win all battles on all three Fronts for two turns in a row, you achieve a Decisive Victory. If the Arabs run out of unit cards, you achieve an Attrition Victory.

The Unit cards are intended to represent Arab and Israeli forces involved in the 1948 hostilities. Units are drawn and played to the Fronts - Arab units to designated Fronts and Israeli cards as desired by the player. Each turn one card is drawn from the Event deck. The Event card confers benefits to one side or the other.

Name: Arabia
Description:
A simple boardgame of high adventure in the mysterious lands of Arabia. The game is played on a square track with 10 spaces per side (for a total of 36 spaces) with the corners designated as Baghdad, Mecca, Medina, and the Silk Road. All other spaces are empty and large enough to hold one of the Adventure Cards. The Adventure Deck and discard pile sit in the center of the board.

Players travel around the board acquiring treasures (and trying to steal them from other players). The players also face challenges. If a player fails a challenge, the Challenge Card is placed on the space the player occupies and any player landing on the card must confront the challenge.

The game ends when a player is required to draw a card but there are no cards left in the Adventure Deck. Victory is determined based on the acquisition of Fortune, Fame, and Faith points.

Name: Archmagi
Description:
A strategic scale fantasy wargame depicting the struggle between Mages (Archmagi), who use spells, heroes, monsters, armies, and artifacts to destroy each other and conquer the world.

The game is played on a hex map randomly created during the course of the game, or created using an online random map generator. The players start at the opposite ends of the mapsheet with their randomly selected Archmagi, and a small assortment of units and spells. The goal is to destroy all opposing Archmagi units.

At start, all non-player Archmagi chits, Spell chits, Banner chits, Artifact chits, and Unit chits are set aside to be recruited by the players in the course of the game. Units may only be recruited from the territory in which they originate, e.g. Dwarves in the mountains, Elves in the forest, Trolls in the swamp, etc. The players obtain Artifacts (magic weapons/items) by turning in two reserve Units. Each player receives three randomly selected spells every turn, but a player may only hold a total of seven spells at a time.

Name: Arcology
Description:
A Gin Rummy influenced card game based on the philosophies and theories of the famous architect Paolo Soleri.

The custom deck is composed of five types of cards: Arcology, Structure, Energy, Theory, and Philosophy. The objective of the game is to be the first to build three Arcologies.

A player builds an Arcology by playing a meld of one Arcology card and two of each other type of card. Certain cards count as two cards when building certain Arcologies.

Name: Arena
Description:
“A Game of Fantasy Gladiatorial Combat for 2-6 players. The players take the roles of owners of a team of warriors who do battle in The Arena, a circle of battle, blood and death. Their teams consist of brave Humans, the graceful, catlike Ptemet, the insectoid Keet’Norn, the brutish Orghar, and the deadly Vashail, who battle for glory, money and at their master’s whim. Life is cheap, death is easy, but glory is eternal!”

The players are allocated funds to set up their gladiatorial team. Warriors, weapons and armor must be purchased. In addition, there are campaign rules to chart a team’s progress from one game to the next.

Name: Army Man Backgammon
Description:
This game is played on a Backgammon board using opposing sets of 15 green army men and 15 tan army men (or any other contrasting colors available). The game also requires two six-sided dice.

The types army men are rated based on the weapon carried (which establishes attack range) and stance (which sets the maximum movement and saving throw values). Units that are standing or running can move faster but are more vulnerable, while units that are prone or kneeling can’t move as fast but are less vulnerable.

When one of your men is hit, it is removed from the game. If the piece designated as your Sergeant is removed from the game, then your remaining men must either dig-in or charge on every turn. The winner is the first player to move a man off the opponent’s side of the Backgammon board.

Name: Army of Darkness Skirmish
Description:
It’s good versus “med”-evil in this game of combat based on the Evil Dead film Army of Darkness.

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chess board. Each player controls 18 creatures, represented by miniatures or counters, which are based on characters from the film (such as Ash, Evil Ash, Archers, and Deadite Warriors.) The good guys also have the Deathcoaster car at their disposal.

The object of the game is to eliminate all of the opposing units. The players draw a hand of cards from a common deck and card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.
Families: Movies: Evil Dead / Army of Darkness

Name: Army Quest
Description: A tactical combat rules system for pitting plastic army men against plastic fantasy figures, such as those found in Heroquest (hence the "Quest" name of this game.) The units are rated for hit points, movement allowance, attack range, and hit probability. The player who eliminates all of the opposing pieces wins the game.

Name: The Civil War 1861-1865
Description:
A game for two players; one being the North(Blue) and the other being the South(Gray).  Game is played in alternating Game Turns, each composed of a series of sequential phases.

Part of the One Page War Series

Name: Tula
Description: Tula resembles solitaire & Shanghai. Players use a Piecepack set for the tiles. The tiles are setup in a temple arrangement and can be removed from the temple if they match the stack in either suit or value.

Name: Arc Gammon
Description: A two-player game in the spirit of Backgammon. The game is played on a ring of twelve round spaces numbered one to twelve. Two white six-sided dice and a colored six-sided die are required for play. Each player requires a different colored set of twelve tokens that are capable of being stacked. The game provides several victory conditions: capture all of your opponent’s tokens, occupy any nine spaces, occupy any five spaces in a row, or occupy a defined set of four spaces (12-1-2-3, or 3-4-5-6, or 6-7-8-9, or 9-10-11-12.)
